from [[Hiroshima Prefecture|Hiroshima]] | constituency9 = [[Hiroshima 1st district|1st district]] | term_start9 = 20 October 1996 | term_end9 = | predecessor9 = ''Constituency established'' | successor9 = | majority9 = 117,800 (71.1%) | constituency10 = Former 1st district
(Elect Four) | term_start10 = 18 July 1993 | term_end10 = 27 September 1996 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1957|7|29|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Shibuya]], [[Tokyo]], Japan | death_date = | death_place = | party = [[Liberal Democratic Party (Japan)|Liberal Democratic]] | education = [[Kaisei Academy]] | alma_mater = [[Waseda University]] ([[Bachelor of Laws|LLB]]) | spouse = {{marriage|[[Yuko Kishida]]|1988}} | children = 3 | signature = Fumio Kishida signature.svg }} {{nihongo|'''Fumio Kishida'''|岸田 文雄|Kishida Fumio|extra=born 29 July 1957 }} is a Japanese politician serving as [[Prime Minister of Japan]] and president of the [[Liberal Democratic Party (Japan)|Liberal Democratic Party]] (LDP) since 2021. A member of the [[House of Representatives of Japan|House of Representatives]], he previously served as [[Minister for Foreign Affairs (Japan)|Minister for Foreign Affairs]] from 2012 to 2017 and as acting [[Minister of Defense (Japan)|Minister of Defense]] in 2017. From 2017 to 2020, he also chaired the LDP Policy Research Council. Born into a political family, Kishida spent part of his childhood in the [[United States]] where he attended elementary school in [[New York City]].{{Cite web|date=3 September 2021|title=Japan's Next Prime Minister: Who Are the Candidates to Succeed Yoshihide Suga?|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/japans-next-prime-minister-who-are-the-candidates-to-succeed-yoshihide-suga-11630657293|access-date=28 September 2021|website=Wall Street Journal|first=Peter|last=Landers|language=en-US|archive-date=28 September 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210928162940/https://www.wsj.com/articles/japans-next-prime-minister-who-are-the-candidates-to-succeed-yoshihide-suga-11630657293|url-status=live}} After beginning his career in finance, Kishida entered politics and was elected to the House of Representatives in [[1993 Japanese general election|1993]] as a member of the LDP. Kishida was appointed to various posts in the cabinets of Prime Ministers [[Shinzo Abe]] and [[Yasuo Fukuda]] from 2007 to 2008, and was appointed Minister for Foreign Affairs in 2012 after Abe regained the premiership following the [[2012 Japanese general election|2012 general election]], serving for five years and becoming the longest-serving Foreign Affairs Minister in Japanese history. Kishida later resigned from the Abe cabinet in 2017 in order to head the LDP's Policy Research Council. Kishida also assumed control of the LDP's [[Kōchikai]] faction in 2012 following the retirement of faction boss [[Makoto Koga]]. Long considered a potential future prime minister, Kishida ran in the [[2020 Liberal Democratic Party (Japan) leadership election|2020 LDP leadership election]], but lost out to [[Yoshihide Suga]].{{Cite web|url=https://asia.nikkei.com/Spotlight/The-Big-Story/Leading-by-listening-Kishida-offers-Japan-a-traditional-style-of-politics|title=Leading by listening: Kishida offers Japan a traditional style of politics|access-date=31 October 2021|archive-date=31 October 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211031170238/https://asia.nikkei.com/Spotlight/The-Big-Story/Leading-by-listening-Kishida-offers-Japan-a-traditional-style-of-politics|url-status=live}} He ran again for the party leadership in [[2021 Liberal Democratic Party (Japan) leadership election|2021]], this time winning in a second round run-off against opponent [[Taro Kono]]. Kishida was confirmed as Prime Minister by the [[National Diet]] four days later on 4 October 2021 and led the LDP to victory in the [[2021 Japanese general election|2021 general election]] later that same month.{{Cite news|date=4 October 2021|title=Fumio Kishida: Japan's new prime minister takes office|language=en-GB|work=BBC News|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-58784635|access-date=4 October 2021|archive-date=4 October 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211004052101/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-58784635|url-status=live}} Kishida has been described as an ideological [[Political moderate|moderate]] within the LDP and has stated that his premiership will focus on a "new model of [[capitalism]]", by seeking to implement [[Redistribution of income and wealth|redistributive policies]] to expand the [[middle class]]. On foreign policy he plans to continue strengthening the [[Quadrilateral Security Dialogue|Quad Security Dialogue]] in pursuit of the [[Free and Open Indo-Pacific]] strategy.{{cite web |url=https://thediplomat.com/2021/09/the-arrival-of-kishida-diplomacy/ |title=The Arrival of Kishida Diplomacy? |last1=Akimoto |first1=Daisuke |date=7 September 2021 |website=The Diplomat |language=en-US |access-date=29 September 2021 |archive-date=28 September 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210928162945/https://thediplomat.com/2021/09/the-arrival-of-kishida-diplomacy/ |url-status=live }} ==Early life and education== Kishida was born to a political family in [[Shibuya]], [[Tokyo]], on 29 July 1957.{{cite web|title=Fumio Kishida|url=https://japan.kantei.go.jp/96_abe/meibo/daijin/kishida_e.html|publisher=Kantei|access-date=30 September 2021|archive-date=28 September 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210928163701/https://japan.kantei.go.jp/96_abe/meibo/daijin/kishida_e.html|url-status=live}}{{cite news|title=Abe Cabinet (Formed December 26, 2012)|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/cabinet-profiles/abe-cabinet-formed-december-26-2012|access-date=30 September 2021|newspaper=The Japan Times|archive-date=30 September 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210930134100/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/cabinet-profiles/abe-cabinet-formed-december-26-2012|url-status=live}} His father Fumitake Kishida was a government official in the [[Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry]] and director of The Small and Medium Enterprise Agency. Since the Kishida family was from [[Hiroshima]], the family returned there every summer. Many members of the Kishida family had died in the [[Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki|atomic bombing]] and Fumio grew up hearing stories from the atomic bomb survivors.{{harvnb|『核兵器のない世界へ』}}: 第一章 故郷・広島への想い Both his father Fumitake and grandfather Masaki Kishida were former politicians who were members of the House of Representatives. Former [[Minister of Economy, Trade and Industry]] [[Yoichi Miyazawa]] is his cousin{{Cite web|date=2020-09-09|title=［自民党総裁選］岸田さんこんな人…「勝つまで戦う」酒豪 : トピックス : ニュース|url=https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/topics/20200909-OYT8T50012/|website=読売新聞オンライン|language=ja|access-date=2020-09-19|archive-date=4 October 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211004110126/https://www.yomiuri.co.jp/topics/20200909-OYT8T50012/|url-status=live}}{{cite web|date=23 October 2014|title=Japan minister support staff 'put sex club on expenses'|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-29735264|access-date=24 October 2014|publisher=[[BBC]]|archive-date=24 October 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141024054943/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-29735264|url-status=live}} and former prime minister [[Kiichi Miyazawa]] is a distant relative of his. He went to [[New York City Department of Education|P.S. 013 Clement C. Moore]] elementary school in the [[Elmhurst, Queens|Elmhurst]] neighborhood of [[Queens]], New York, because his father was posted to a job in the U.S. at the time. He also attended Kōjimachi Elementary School and Kōjimachi Junior High School. Kishida graduated from [[Kaisei Academy]], where he also played on the [[baseball]] team.{{cite news |last=Sin |first=Walter |date=2 October 2021 |title=Fumio Kishida: Japan's ronin turned prime minister-designate |url=https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/fumio-kishida-japans-ronin-turned-prime-minister-designate |work=[[The Straits Times]] |access-date=4 October 2021 |archive-date=3 October 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211003211726/https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/fumio-kishida-japans-ronin-turned-prime-minister-designate |url-status=live }} Following several rejections from the [[University of Tokyo]], Kishida studied law at [[Waseda University]] and graduated in 1982. At Waseda, he was friends with future politician [[Takeshi Iwaya]].{{Cite news |last1=Reynolds |first1 =Isabel |last2=Hirokawa |first2=Takashi |date=20 July 2017 |title=Abe's Low-Key Foreign Minister Watched as Potential Rival |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-07-20/abe-s-low-key-foreign-minister-emerges-as-key-rival-to-run-japan |language=en |work=Bloomberg.com |access-date=29 August 2020 |archive-date=29 September 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210929144248/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-07-20/abe-s-low-key-foreign-minister-emerges-as-key-rival-to-run-japan |url-status=live}}{{cite news |agency=Agence France-Presse |title=Fumio Kishida: calm centrist picked as Japan's next prime minister |url=https://newsinfo.inquirer.net/1494663/fumio-kishida-calm-centrist-picked-as-japans-next-prime-minister |access-date=8 October 2021 |work=INQUIRER.net |date=29 September 2021 |language=en |archive-date=8 October 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211008164649/https://newsinfo.inquirer.net/1494663/fumio-kishida-calm-centrist-picked-as-japans-next-prime-minister |url-status=live }} ==Political career== After working at now-defunct [[Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan]] and then as a secretary to a member of the House of Representatives, Kishida was elected to the House of Representatives in the [[1993 Japanese general election|1993 general election]], representing the Hiroshima 1st district.{{cite news|title=Profiles of key ministers in Abe's new Cabinet|url=http://ajw.asahi.com/article/behind_news/politics/AJ201212260086|access-date=27 December 2012|newspaper=The Asahi Shimbun|date=26 December 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130705190313/http://ajw.asahi.com/article/behind_news/politics/AJ201212260086|archive-date=5 July 2013|url-status=dead}} Kishida served as Minister of Okinawa Affairs from 2007 to 2008, firstly in the Abe Cabinet and later in the Fukuda cabinet.{{cite news|date=27 December 2012|title=Profile: Foreign Minister Kishida boasts background in Okinawa affairs|newspaper=House of Japan|url=http://www.houseofjapan.com/local/profile-foreign-minister-kishida-boasts-background-in-okinawa-affairs|url-status=dead|access-date=3 January 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202225149/http://www.houseofjapan.com/local/profile-foreign-minister-kishida-boasts-background-in-okinawa-affairs|archive-date=2 December 2013}} He was appointed state minister in charge of consumer affairs and food safety in the cabinet of then prime minister [[Yasuo Fukuda]] in 2008. Kishida was also state minister in charge of science and technology in the Fukuda cabinet. He was close to [[Makoto Koga]], leader of the [[Kōchikai]] faction, one of the oldest inside the LDP, and assumed control of it in October 2012 after Makoto Koga announced his retirement from politics. === Abe government === [[File:PM Modi meets Minister of Foreign Affairs, Fumio Kishida, in Tokyo.jpg|thumb|left|Kishida with Indian Prime Minister [[Narendra Modi]], September 2014]] Following the LDP's victory in the [[2012 Japanese general election|2012 general election]], Kishida was named foreign minister in the Cabinet of Prime Minister [[Shinzō Abe]] on 26 December 2012.{{cite news|title=Abe elected premier, launches Cabinet|url=http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/national/T121226002018.htm|access-date=3 January 2013|newspaper=Daily Yomuiru Online|date=26 December 2012|archive-date=30 December 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121230194816/http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/national/T121226002018.htm|url-status=live}} He became the longest-serving foreign minister in postwar history, surpassing Abe's father [[Shintaro Abe]].{{Cite web|last=Bosack|first=Michael|date=9 July 2018|title=Will Kishida Challenge Abe's Leadership?|url=https://www.tokyoreview.net/2018/07/kishida-abe-leadership-challenge/|access-date=29 August 2020|website=Tokyo Review|archive-date=20 August 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200820065646/https://www.tokyoreview.net/2018/07/kishida-abe-leadership-challenge/|url-status=live}} He helped to arrange U.S. President [[Barack Obama]]'s historic visit to [[Hiroshima]] in May 2016, and gained attention in 2017 when he appeared alongside comedian [[Daimaou Kosaka|Piko Taro]] to promote a United Nations program. He was not in favor of the appointment of [[Toshihiro Nikai]] as LDP secretary-general by Abe in 2016 against the wishes of Kishida's own faction, which was seen as an attempt at blocking generational change inside the LDP.{{Cite web|date=11 September 2021|title=Kishida goes all out for Japan's top job|url=https://www.eastasiaforum.org/2021/09/11/kishida-goes-all-out-for-japans-top-job/|access-date=28 September 2021|website=East Asia Forum|archive-date=28 September 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210928162941/https://www.eastasiaforum.org/2021/09/11/kishida-goes-all-out-for-japans-top-job/|url-status=live}} In 2017, Kishida left the Cabinet to take over the chairmanship of the LDP Policy Research Council, a position traditionally seen as a stepping stone to leadership of the party.{{Cite news|date=2 August 2017|title=Japanese Foreign Minister Kishida set to take key ruling party post: NHK|work=Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-japan-politics-idUSKBN1AI073|access-date=29 August 2020|archive-date=22 September 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200922185255/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-japan-politics-idUSKBN1AI073|url-status=live}} He sought this position in order to improve his chances to succeed Abe, as the foreign minister post had relatively little influence within the party. Kishida considered running in the [[2018 Liberal Democratic Party (Japan) leadership election|2018 LDP presidential election]], but he was persuaded by Abe not to run, with a suggestion that Abe would later support Kishida as his successor.{{Cite web|last=Yoshida|first=Reiji|date=24 July 2018|title=LDP policy chief Fumio Kishida says he won't run in party leadership election, leaving two-way race between Abe and Ishiba|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2018/07/24/national/politics-diplomacy/ldp-policy-chief-fumio-kishida-says-wont-run-partys-election-leaving-two-way-race-abe-ishiba/|access-date=4 October 2021|website=The Japan Times|language=en-US|archive-date=4 October 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211004062900/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2018/07/24/national/politics-diplomacy/ldp-policy-chief-fumio-kishida-says-wont-run-partys-election-leaving-two-way-race-abe-ishiba/|url-status=live}} By mid-2020, several senior LDP lawmakers had shifted their support from Kishida to Chief Cabinet Secretary [[Yoshihide Suga]]. Deputy Prime Minister [[Tarō Asō|Taro Aso]] was also popular for sending stimulus payments to households during the [[COVID-19 pandemic in Japan|COVID-19 pandemic]].{{Cite web|last=Sakaguchi|first=Yukihiro|date=26 June 2020|title=Race to replace Abe threatens stability of Japanese politics|url=https://asia.nikkei.com/Politics/Inside-Japanese-politics/Race-to-replace-Abe-threatens-stability-of-Japanese-politics|access-date=29 August 2020|website=Nikkei Asian Review|archive-date=28 August 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200828215542/https://asia.nikkei.com/Politics/Inside-Japanese-politics/Race-to-replace-Abe-threatens-stability-of-Japanese-politics|url-status=live}} After Suga won the [[2020 Liberal Democratic Party (Japan) leadership election|2020 LDP presidential election]] and became Prime Minister, Kishida was not offered a position in the Suga cabinet, although his faction obtained two cabinet seats.{{Cite web|last=Bosack|first=Michael MacArthur|date=16 September 2020|title=Breaking down Suga's picks for his first Cabinet|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/opinion/2020/09/16/commentary/japan-commentary/yoshihide-suga-cabinet-rundown/|access-date=16 September 2020|website=The Japan Times|archive-date=18 September 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200918052325/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/opinion/2020/09/16/commentary/japan-commentary/yoshihide-suga-cabinet-rundown/|url-status=live}} ===Prime Minister of Japan=== {{See also|2021 Liberal Democratic Party (Japan) leadership election|First Kishida Cabinet|Second Kishida Cabinet|Second Kishida Cabinet (Reshuffled)}} [[File:The Prime Minister, Shri Narendra Modi at the QUAD Leaders’ Family Photo, in Tokyo, Japan on May 24, 2022.jpg|thumb|right|Fumio Kishida at the May 2022 [[Quadrilateral Security Dialogue]] meeting with Australian prime minister [[Anthony Albanese]], US president [[Joe Biden]] and Indian prime minister [[Narendra Modi]]]] On 29 September 2021, Kishida defeated [[Taro Kono]] in [[2021 Liberal Democratic Party (Japan) leadership election|a runoff vote to become the leader]] of the ruling [[Liberal Democratic Party (Japan)|Liberal Democratic Party]] (LDP) and replaced outgoing party leader [[Yoshihide Suga]]. He received a total of 257 votes, from 249 parliament members and eight rank-and-file members, to become Japan's next Prime Minister.{{cite news |last1=Ogura |first1=Junko |last2=Wang |first2=Selina |last3=Regan |first3=Helen |title=Fumio Kishida expected to become Japan's next Prime Minister after ruling party vote |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2021/09/29/asia/japan-leadership-election-kishida-intl-hnk/index.html |date=29 September 2021 |access-date=29 September 2021 |website=CNN |archive-date=29 September 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210929070431/https://edition.cnn.com/2021/09/29/asia/japan-leadership-election-kishida-intl-hnk/index.html |url-status=live }} The [[First Kishida Cabinet]] took office on 4 October 2021 and consisted of 21 members, including 13 who joined the Cabinet for the first time while also including 2 veterans, [[Toshimitsu Motegi]] and [[Nobuo Kishi]] who retained their respective posts from the [[Suga Cabinet|previous cabinet under Suga]];{{cite news |last1=Sim |first1=Walter |title=Who's who in Cabinet of Japan's new PM Fumio Kishida |url=https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/whos-who-in-the-cabinet-of-japans-new-pm-fumio-kishida |access-date=4 October 2021 |work=The Straits Times |date=4 October 2021 |language=en |archive-date=6 October 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211006091010/https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/whos-who-in-the-cabinet-of-japans-new-pm-fumio-kishida |url-status=live }} however, on the same day, Kishida announced he would call a [[2021 Japanese general election|general election for 31 October 2021]].{{Cite news|last=Lies|first=Elaine|date=3 October 2021|title=In surprise move, new Japan PM to call Oct 31 election - NHK|language=en|work=Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/japans-kishida-set-take-office-form-government-2021-10-03/|access-date=4 October 2021|archive-date=4 October 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211004042842/https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/japans-kishida-set-take-office-form-government-2021-10-03/|url-status=live}} Kishida gave his first speech as prime minister on 8 October 2021, vowing to fight and end the [[COVID-19 pandemic in Japan]] as well as announcing measures to counter the perceived threats by China and North Korea.{{cite news |title=Japan's new PM promises to do his utmost to end COVID-19 crisis |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/10/8/japans-new-pm-promises-to-do-his-utmost-to-end-covid-19-crisis |access-date=8 October 2021 |agency=[[Al Jazeera]] |date=8 October 2021 |archive-date=8 October 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211008081958/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/10/8/japans-new-pm-promises-to-do-his-utmost-to-end-covid-19-crisis |url-status=live }} Following the [[2021 Japanese general election]], Kishida maintained the premiership although the LDP lost 25 seats. He formed the [[Second Kishida Cabinet]] by replacing [[Toshimitsu Motegi]] with [[Yoshimasa Hayashi]] as the Foreign Minister; Motegi became the party's Secretary-General.{{Cite web |title=Japan foreign minister Motegi to become ruling party No. 2 |url=https://english.kyodonews.net/news/2021/11/3dce4fe535b4-update1-japan-foreign-minister-motegi-to-become-ruling-party-no-2.html |access-date=2021-11-01 |website=Kyodo News+}} [[File:Fumio Kishida announced additional sanction during the G7 Scholss Elmau Summit (3).jpg|thumb|Fumio Kishida at the [[48th G7 summit]] in Schloss Elmau, Germany in June 2022]] On 24 February 2022, following the beginning of the [[2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine|Russian invasion of Ukraine]], Kishida joined other leaders of the [[Group of Seven|G-7]] nations in imposing [[economic sanctions]] on [[Russia]]. Kishida's proposed sanctions are much harsher than the largely symbolic sanctions imposed by the government of [[Shinzo Abe]] on Russia following the [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|2014 Russian annexation of Crimea]]. Liberal Democratic Party leaders fear that a lackluster response by Japan to the Ukrainian crisis will result in a lack of support from Japan's European allies in the event of [[Chinese unification|potential Chinese aggression against Taiwan]].{{cite news |last1=Lee |first1=Michelle Ye Hee |title=Japan cautiously moves toward stern response to Russia after years of trying to improve relations |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2022/02/24/japan-russia-sanctions/ |access-date=Feb 24, 2022 |agency=The Washington Post}} After the [[assassination of Shinzo Abe]] on 8 July 2022, Kishida condemned the assassination,{{Cite web |title='Absolutely unforgiveable': Japan PM Kishida strongly condemns shooting of Shinzo Abe |url=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/asia/shinzo-abe-shooting-grave-condition-japan-pm-kishida-condemns-unforgiveable-2796271 |date=2022-07-08 |website=CNA |language=en}} but refused to suspend political campaigning so as to demonstrate that democracy would not be impeded by violence. He later blamed insufficient police protection for allowing the murder to occur.{{Cite web |first=Mari |last=Yamaguchi |title=Japan PM blames police for death of former leader Shinzo Abe |url=https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/japan-pm-blames-police-death-leader-shinzo-abe-86800698 |access-date=2022-07-14 |website=ABC News |language=en}} Because of media reports on the ties between the LDP and the [[Unification Church]], a Korean cult accused of scamming Japanese followers (including the suspect's mother) out of much of their wealth, Kishida [[Second Kishida Cabinet (Reshuffled)|reshuffled his Cabinet]] on 10 August 2022, which included removing Abe's brother, [[Nobuo Kishi]], from the role of Minister of Defense.{{Cite web |title=Japan PM revamps Cabinet to reverse flagging public support |url=https://english.kyodonews.net/news/2022/08/ee92908726d4-japan-pm-to-reshuffle-cabinet-ldp-leadership-as-public-support-slips.html |date=2022-08-10 |website=Kyodo News+}} While the majority of members of the LDP, including Shinzo Abe and Nobuo Kishi, were related to the church to various degrees, there were no evidences of Kishida having any direct tie with the church or any of its affiliated entities.{{citation |url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/podcast/unification-church-kishida/ |title=The Church, the State and Kishida's headache |work=[[The Japan Times]] |date=2022-12-07 |accessdate=2022-12-14 }} However, it was reported in the 1 September issue of ''[[Shūkan Bunshun]]'' that {{ill|Mineo Nakayama|ja|中山峰男}}, the president of a Kumamoto circle for backing Kishida's bidding of the premiership was also a chairperson of a Unification Church-affiliated group which was advocating for building the [[Japan-Korea Undersea Tunnel]]. Both Kishida and Nakayama denied any knowledge of the tunnel advocacy group being related to the Unification Church.{{citation |url=https://news.yahoo.co.jp/articles/0146b8d2f558a6f43c02e1475ee9c1dddd9980e6 |title=「憤り感じる」「学生に教会の勧誘が及ばないように」岸田総理の後援会長 崇城大・中山学長が会見 |work=[[Abema Times]] |date=2022-08-24 |accessdate=2022-08-28 |language=ja }} In November 2022, Kishida instructed his government to increase military spending to 2 percent of Japan's GDP, up from 1 percent previously, by 2027.{{Cite news |date=2022-11-28 |title=Japan’s Kishida Orders Defense Spending Hike to 2% of GDP |language=en |work=Bloomberg.com |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-11-28/japan-pm-orders-security-spending-hike-to-2-of-gdp-tbs-says |access-date=2022-11-30}} ==Political views== Kishida is seen as dovish on foreign policy and lukewarm about revising Japan's pacifist constitution.{{Cite web|date=3 September 2021|title=Factbox: Possible candidates to become Japan's next prime minister|url=https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/potential-candidates-become-japans-next-prime-minister-2021-09-03/|access-date=28 September 2021|website=Reuters|language=en-US|archive-date=27 September 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210927222300/https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/potential-candidates-become-japans-next-prime-minister-2021-09-03/|url-status=live}} Following the political philosophy of his own faction, Kishida has pledged a "humane diplomacy" based on the [[Constitution of Japan|Peace Constitution]], the [[Treaty of Mutual Cooperation and Security Between the United States and Japan|Japan–U.S. alliance]], and the [[Japan Self-Defense Forces|Self-Defense Forces]] and that he will seek to strengthen Japan–U.S. relations and to promote the [[Free and Open Indo-Pacific|free and open Indo-Pacific]] (FOIP) strategy while counterbalancing Chinese political assertiveness and military presence in the region. Regarding Chinese influence over [[Taiwan]] and [[Hong Kong]], Kishida has stated that the Taiwan Strait may be the "next major diplomatic problem" following "China's clampdown on Hong Kong" and that Japan should seek more cooperation with Taiwan.{{Cite web|date=3 September 2021|title=Fumio Kishida, top contender to lead Japan, warns Taiwan is 'next big problem'|url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2021/09/03/national/politics-diplomacy/fumio-kishida-taiwan/|access-date=28 September 2021|website=The Japan Times|language=en-US|archive-date=28 leader of the moderate [[Kōchikai]] faction,{{Cite journal|date=31 December 2011|title=Kochikai of the Japanese Liberal Democratic Party and Its Evolution After the Cold
